awd_titl_txt: Cationic gold-antimony complexes: Synthesis and electrophilic properties.
awd_abstract_narration:
A catalyst is a substance that speeds or otherwise facilitates a chemical reaction. Catalysts are critical to the chemical and pharmaceutical industries, where they are used to reduce the energy required for chemical reactions and to guide the details of precise chemical transformations. While gold is an expensive element, many catalysts incorporate it.  Improving gold catalysts is an important area of investigation. In this project, funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Francois Gabbai of the Department of Chemistry at Texas A&M University seeks to improve the catalytic properties of gold by combining it with antimony, a non-metallic element. The antimony is able to combine with gold in a way that enhances gold's reactivity. The gold-antimony compounds that are isolated are developed into catalysts for the activation of alkenes, which are major chemical industry feedstocks.  Professor Gabbai participates in outreach programs to K-6 students in Spanish/English dual language programs in order to interest young students in science and technology.

This research project investigates the chemistry of gold (Au) complexes featuring ambiphilic ligands comprised of two phosphine donors and an antimony moiety. The central objective is to determine if the charge of the antimony (Sb) ligand can be used to modulate the electrophilic character and catalytic properties of the gold center. A series of dinuclear complexes with a gold atom held in close proximity to a pentavalent antimony center are synthesized and ligand abstraction reactions generate complexes in which the pentavalent antimony center is either monocationic or dicationic.  Structural, spectroscopic and computational studies indicate if the accumulation of positive character on the antimony ligand promotes a donor-acceptor Au-Sb interaction.  A correlation between the charge of the antimony ligand and the electrophilic reactivity of the gold center is indicated by the catalytic activation of alkenes in polymerization and hydroamination reactions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Varying the charge of a transition metal center may influence its hardness, redox properties, and catalytic activity. In this project, we investigated a variant of this approach based on the incorporation of a charged entity at a position directly adjacent to the metal center. Using a series of antimony-gold and -platinum complexes, we demonstrated that the σ-accepting properties of the antimony center scale with its positive charge, leading to a net enhancement in the electrophilic reactivity of the adjoining late transition metal center. We thus propose that the intellectual merit of this project lies in the use of charged antimony moieties as Z-type ligands and the demonstration that the elevated Lewis acidity of these group 15 fragments can be transferred to an otherwise soft late transition metal, enhancing the electrophilic reactivity of the latter. This project has also allowed us to demonstrate that these charge effects may be operative in systems containing cationic carbon- or germanium-based Lewis acids as σ-accepting ligands. We contend that the generalization of these ligand-centered charge effects adds to the intellectual merit of our NSF-supported activities. This award has also enabled us to continue our fundamental investigations into the chemistry of main group Lewis acids.

This project has contributed to the training of 13 graduate students. Seven of these students, who have already obtained their graduate degrees, are currently employed as postdoctoral fellows, researchers in the chemical industry, or instructors at academic institutions. All other students who benefited from this award will graduate in the next three years. In addition to contributing to the training of a diverse cohort of students, this project has allowed all group members to engage in several service and outreach activities, including the organization of conferences, scientific editing, outreach at community events, and in local middle schools and high schools.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2023
Modified by: Francois P Gabbai
